title: Is possible create a BOOT BIOS entry?

forumNotes.author: ewqa
forumNotes.content:
Hello, I've learned a lot from this forum on boot different operating systems with EasyBCD, BootICE, grub4dos, etc.. But what I do not meeting for any site on google or reboot.pro and would like you to help me solve it.  

I want to add a boot entry to the BIOS to call any partition of my hard drive to boot regardless in case of mbr main failure.  

![Posted Image](http://www.besttechtips.net/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/boot-menu.png)  

I say this because all the ways described in this forum depend on the main mbr, but I do not know if you can use another mbr in case of failure of the principal.  

I know that with boot usbs and cds could be solved but , What happens if I have none at that time?.  

PXE not worth for me because I will not hold anything out of my hard drive.  

Is there any way to do or is not possible?.  

Sorry for my english and thank you.

forumNotes.author: 0scar
forumNotes.content:
Modding the bios is possible, there are tools for editing the bios, but it is too easy to brick the motherboard.  
Search in Google, for ex. [http://home.arcor.de.../bmreport1.html](http://home.arcor.de/frogge/pepper/bmreport1.html "External link")

forumNotes.author: sbaeder
forumNotes.content:
I would agree with the above. Modifying the BIOS (or even the UEFI going forward) is a complex and tricky proposition. Even "experts" have problems doing this!  

Best bet would be to have a USB drive with a good MBR (or bootable environment) that can be used to "repair" a faulty MBR. But just a question...How often or likely is it to be the case that you have a bad MBR and can't boot - AND you don't have access to a USB or CD?   

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Scott

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
Something that you can do with no risk, is to use a network card (actually the EPROM/EEPROM/Flash on it) as an "Extension Bios".  

Among the various things that you can put on it there are PLoP and Wee, both of which could represent a "failsafe booting".  

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Wonko

forumNotes.author: sbaeder
forumNotes.content:
yes, adding a bootable rom (and a NIC is a good way to cheaply add this - I hadn't thought of it before ![:good:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/good.gif) ) You would still need to do the work to make that ROM, and add in the code to be able to repair the MBR that was corrupted, etc. So, making a bootable ROM and using a NIC card to access it (at least when there is the ability to have a NIC boot rom) is possibly viable.   

But seems it would be simple and inexpensive to just make a bootable USB, and throw it onto a [micro USB stick](https://www.google.com/search?q=micro+usb+stick&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8&aq=t&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&client=firefox-a&channel=fflb "External link") that you leave plugged in at all times. Then it works for a laptop, or a case where you have the NIC on the motherboard without an option ROM available, etc... And, my experience has been that if the MBR is non-functional, that you need more tools to fix things, since access to the other disks or partitions on any hard drive may not be functional. This way you can update it when you need to, but even set it up so it isn't even mounted by Windows (by default)...  

In any case, good luck, and if you do build a ROM module, let us know!  

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Scott
